verses.verse: ((3 The constancy and perfectness of Job.13 The reward of the wicked and of the tyrants.) ) Moreover Job proceeded and continued his parable, saying,

The living God hath taken away my (He hath so sore afflicted me, that men cannot judge of mine uprightness: for they judge only by outward signs.) judgment: for the Almighty hath put my soul in bitterness.
Yet so long as my breath is in me, and the Spirit of God in my nostrils,

(However men judge of me, yet will I not speak contrary to that which I have said, and so do wickedly in betraying the truth.) My lips surely shall speak no wickedness, and my tongue shall utter no deceit.

God forbid, that I should (Which condemns me as a wicked man, because the hand of God is upon me.) justify you: until I die, I will never take away mine (I will not confess that God doth thus punish me for my sins.) innocency from myself.
I will keep my righteousness, and will not forsake it: mine heart shall not reprove me of my (Of my life past.) days.
Mine enemy shall be as the wicked, and he that riseth against me, as the unrighteous.
For what (What advantage hath the dissembler to gain never so much, seeing he shall lose his own soul?) hope hath the hypocrite when he hath heaped up riches, if God take away his soul?
Will God hear his cry, when trouble cometh upon him?
Will he set his delight on the Almighty? will he call upon God at all times?
I will teach you what is in the hand of (That is, what God reserveth to himself, and whereof he giveth not the knowledge to all.) God, and I will not conceal that which is with the Almighty.
Behold, all ye yourselves (That is, these secret judgments of God, and yet do not understand them.) have seen it: why then do you thus vanish (Why maintain you then this error?) vanity?
This is the (Thus will God order the wicked, and punish him even unto his posterity.) portion of a wicked man with God, and the heritage of tyrants, which they shall receive of the Almighty.
If his children be in great number, the sword shall destroy them, and his posterity shall not be satisfied with bread.
His remnant shall be buried in death, and his widows (None shall lament him.) shall not weep.
Though he should heap up silver as the dust, and prepare raiment as the clay,
He may prepare it, but the just shall put it on, and the innocent shall divide the silver.
He buildeth his house as the (Which breedeth in another manâ€™s possession or garment, but is soon shaken out.) moth, and as a lodge that the watchman maketh.

When the rich man sleepeth, (He meaneth, that the wicked tyrants shall not have a quiet death, nor be buried honorably.) he shall not be gathered to his fathers: they opened their eyes, and he was gone.
Terrors shall take him as waters, and a tempest shall carry him away by night.
The East wind shall take him away, and he shall depart: and it shall hurl him out of his place.
And God shall cast upon him and not spare, though he would fain flee out of his hand.
Every man shall clap their hands at him, and hiss at him out of their place.
